choices.B: Create a public subnet for web servers and associate a dynamic routing gateway with that subnet, and a private subnet for database servers with no association to dynamic routing gateway.
choices.D: Create a single public subnet for your web servers and database servers, and associate only your web servers to internet gateway.
choices.A: Create public subnets for web servers and private subnets for database servers in your virtual cloud network (VCN), and associate separate internet gateways for each subnet.
choices.C: Create public subnets for web servers and private subnets for database servers in your VCN, and associate separate security lists and route tables for each subnet.

discussion.content: C is correct. Only option that puts the DB servers in the public subnet and allows for separate access lists and routing for it.

comments.content: right. But the other are totally wrong, then I think that you have to do what reported in C, plus adding an internet gateway(omitted).

discussion.content: C looks correct but without Internet Gateway how it can be accessed.
Deep cloud architecture experience from other cloud. I would go with A!

comments.content: Incorrect, its just confusing with Option C (which is the right option). You cannot have Internet gateways at subnet level. You only have 1 IGW for a VCN.
both are wrong, you can have an internet gateway at subnet level. But internet gateway works only with public subnet.

questions.question_text:
You are designing a two-tier web application in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI). Your clients want to access the web servers from anywhere, but want to prevent access to the database servers from the Internet.
Which is the recommended way to design the network architecture?

choices.A: You can associate a bucket with multiple compartments
choices.C: You can associate a bucket with only a single compartment
choices.D: You cannot edit or append data to an object, but you can replace the entire object
choices.B: You cannot change a bucket from private to public after it is created

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about an Oracle Cloud Infrastructure object storage bucket? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: The answer is rightly C and D

comments.content:
How did you take regularly a backup in noarchivelog mode?

BC
B&C. https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Database/Troubleshooting/Backup/backupfail.htm says NOARCHIVELOG is one of the issues that causes the failure.
You got it wrong. Archive mode is disabled when set to NOARCHIVELOG.
Archive mode is enabled if the database archiving mode is set to NOARCHIVELOG. So the answer should be A and B

discussion.content: B & C - For the DB backup to complete while it is running. Archive mode needs to be enabled.
B & C - is the correct answer
A is wrong, ARCHIVELOG is the required archiving mode for backup operations, turning off the archivelog will cause backup error. So the options are B and C

comments.content: if you set the the archive mode to NOARCHIVELOG, thre is nothing to backup. because the only backup option will be offline backup

discussion.content:
A)
To check and set the archiving mode
https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Database/Troubleshooting/Backup/backupfail.htm

B)
Object Store Connectivity Issues

NOT C)
Doc: “Occasionally you might need to restart the dcsagent program if it has the status of stop/waiting to resolve a backup failure.”

Restart is a solution, it isn´t a way to determine the cause.

NOT D)
“To check that the database is active and running”
https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Database/Troubleshooting/Backup/backupfail.htm

B : Backing up your database to Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Object Storage requires that the host can connect to the applicable Swift endpoint. You can test this connectivity by using a Swift user.

C : Your Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Database makes use of an agent framework to allow you to manage your database through the cloud platform. Occasionally you might need to restart the dcsagent program if it has the status of stop/waiting to resolve a backup failure.

comments.content:
https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Database/Troubleshooting/Backup/backupfail.htm
Refer sections: Host Issues (B) & Database Service Agent Issues (C)

choices.C: Restart the dcsagent program if it has a status of stop or waiting
choices.A: Ensure the database archiving mode is set to NOARCHIVELOG
choices.D: Make sure that the database is not active and running while the backup is in progress
choices.B: Ensure that your database host can connect to the OCI object storage

questions.question_text:
You are running a mission-critical database application in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI). You take regular backups of your DB system to OCI object storage.
Recently, you notice a failed database backup status in the console.
What two steps can you take to determine the cause of the backup failure? (Choose two.)

choices.C: Users can customize OCIDs for all the resources in their compartments.
choices.B: If you delete a user, and them create a new user with the same name, the user will be considered a different user because of different OCIDs.
choices.D: If you delete a user, and then create a new user with the same name, the new user will be assigned the exact same OCIDs as the system remembers.

questions.question_text: Which statement is true about Oracle Cloud Identifiers (OCID)?

You are about to upload a large log file (5 TiB size) to Oracle Cloud Infrastructure object storage and have decided to use multipart upload capability for a more efficient and resilient upload.
Which two statements are true about multipart upload? (Choose two.)

choices.C: The maximum size for an uploaded object is 10 TiB
choices.A: Individual object parts can be as small as 10 MiB or as large as 50 GiB
choices.D: You do not have to commit the upload after you have uploaded all the object parts
choices.B: While a multipart upload is still active, you cannot add parts even if the total number of parts is less than 10,000
